repnme.cdata!:
Timor Leste - Power Sector Priority
            Investments Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Power Sector Priority
            Investments Project for Timor Leste were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            capacity of a power utility management contractor for
            project implementation may well be limited unless provisions
            for the management of capital projects are included in its
            contract. Thus, utility management contracts should include
            management of foreseen capital projects and capacity
            building of utility staff in their scope of
            responsibilities. Timely and professional supervision of the
            management contract is essential. A recent consultant review
            of the performance under the first management contract
            highlighted the failure to monitor the contract properly, as
            well as the difficult operating environment, as critical
            reasons for the poor performance overall under the contract.
            Realistic risk assessment and appropriate implementation
            arrangements for contingency plans to cover downside risks
            as cost overruns are essential for ensuring project quality
            at entry.

5754524.trustfund:
TF053898-TFET : POWER SECTOR PRIORITY
            INVESTMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Timor Leste - Power Sector Priority
            Investments Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Power
            Sector Priority Investments Project, is the delivery of
            least-cost, high-quality electricity service, with minimum
            dependence on the government's budget. This objective
            will be attained through improvements in the Timor Leste
            Electricity (EDTL) generation capacity, generation and
            distribution efficiency, and, through savings achieved
            through demand reductions in the use of energy efficient
            lamps and light bulbs. To this end, project components aim:
            1) to enhance base load generation capacity, and reduce fuel
            costs, the unit engine at the Comoro Power Station will be
            replaced with a new 2.8 MW unit; 2). to improve service
            quality, and reduce losses the distribution system at Dili
            will be reinforced, and rehabilitated; 3) to achieve
            reductions in fuel costs incurred by EDTL, the distribution,
            and installation of efficient lamps and light bulbs should
            ensure greater efficiency in energy end-use for lighting;
            and, 4) project management activities will support auditing,
            procurement, and financial management.

repnme.cdata!:
Timor-Leste - Power Sector Priority
            Investments Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental management plan for
            the Timor-Leste Power Sector Priority Investments Project
            mainly discusses the environmental impact of replacing a
            diesel engine at the Comoros Power Plant. Because the newly
            acquired engine is made with recent technology is expected
            to have better environmental performance with respect to
            exhaust gases, emissions, and noise that conform to World
            Bank standards. Sulphur content will likely be lower with
            lower fuel consumption, lower lube oil consumption, exhaust
            gases will have lower temperatures and concentrations of
            nitrous oxide particles and carbon dioxide, as well. Since
            it is only the diesel engine that is being replaced, the
            other peripheral systems have to be maintained: they will
            need to be flushed clean, to prevent oil spills. Waste oil
            will be collected and stored in proper containers in the
            power plant for now and properly disposed of. Training will
            be provided in order to help workers adapt to the new
            engine's operational demands.
